div.p: A MOST GLORIOUS REPRESENTATION OF THE INCOMPARABLE FREE GRACE OF CHRIST, Faithfully, fully, and freely offering himself, at all times, by all manner of means, to all sorts of Sinners, under the sound of the GOSPEL.
Answering all Objections, of all sorts of men, which formerly kept them from coming to Him.

Stating the Question about Universall Redemption, in an unusuall way, whereby to escape the rocks on both sides, on which many have split: Confuting them that do denie Justification by Faith; and others assertion of eternall actuall Justification, before men do beleeve.
Setling many Cases of Conscience that arise in a perplexed Soul about his inward spirituall condition.
AND LASTLY Prescribing severall divine Soliloquies, and Soul-wrastlings with Christ, whereby to fall in, and fully close with him by faith.
Lisenced by Authoritie.
LONDON: Printed by M: Symmons. 1650.

div.head: CHRIST HIS Full and free Offer of himselfe To poore SINNERS.

q.p: Him that commeth to me, I will in no wise cast out.

div.head: CHAP. I The footing and meaning of the maine Proposition of Christs offer of himselfe cleared.
div.p: BEhold here a wonderfull chapter; this is part of the Zodiack, that line of heavenly Gospell, in which the Sunne of Righteousnesse moves, therefore the Climat below in the Church, to seeing men, must needes be full of wonderfull light and glory. Here is nothing but miracula aut miranda, miracles, or marvels: the former setting off the latter; the latter preferred afore the former.

1 Here is a miraculous Epulation; a feeding five thousand with five barley loves, and two small fishes; and that unto such
satiety and alacrity, as if feasted with plenty, and dainties, verse 9, 10, 11, 12. &c. See what browne bread with the Gospel is, when the Provision is but little, and little worth, but the Gospel is come, and become the sauce, there is great cheere, Acts 2.46. Continuing dayly in the Temple, and breaking bread from house to house, they eate their meate with gladnesse and singlenesse of heart.

2. A miraculous evasion, or escape of Christ, from being made King by force. Marvellous not onely in regard of his power, but of his will He was a King, he professeth himselfe to be a King, and that to that end he was borne, and for that cause he came to beare witnesse to the truth, and therefore to that truth, John 18.37. Yet here when he perceived that they would come, and take him by force, and make him a King, he departed into a mountaine himselfe alone. He would not be a King, that he might be a King. He disclaimed Civill pompous Royalty, that he might be proclaimed a Spiritual King. The world from their earthly principles inferre their earthly conclusions: the Heathens (as have the Jewes,) wrote those for Gods that were eminent Authours eorum quae ad victum conducunt of husbandry, victualing of Kingdomes, &c. The Egyptian Apis was invented on some such occasion; and perhaps (as some thinke) in after times upon Josephs saving Egypt in the time of famine. But Christ intends in that miracle of bread, in the miracles of healing diseases, to lead them to consider him as a Spirituall Physician, Matth. 8.17. compare Isay 53.4. to suggest to them that he was the true spirituall bread, ver. 48. And therefore waves the offer of a Crowne for his breaden exploit, and although with violence they would have put it on, he without violence escapes it, and them.

3 A miraculous perambulation; he walkes on the sea, verse 19. not so much to invite a Peter to aske power to doe so too, (and Peters designe in part miscarried, to the feare of his life,) but to cause men to looke higher, viz. that he that now walkes on the fluid flouds, is he that came downe from heaven, God in humane flesh,1 Tim. 3.16. (O the great mystery) and would walke up thither againe upon the non feather-bearing ayre, as upon solid ground, Acts 1. So ver. 38. of this 6. of Iohn I came downe from heaven, ver. 39. That I should rayse them that the Father hath given me, that so they may be where he should be. Chap. 14.2, 3.

But all these are but corporall miracles, they did tend immediately but to the body; but intended to in • scate the bodily sences to guide them thence, and guide the soule towards spirituall maervells; As
1 To those marvellous Expressions, what Christ is. From ver. 22. to the Text. viz. That he is not a Cooke or Kitchen-Christ for the body, but the soule-saving Christ, for a mans spirit.
2 To that marvelous Protestation, who shall have him, and be the better for him spiritually, in the Text: namely, Him that commeth to him, he will in no wise cast out.

Him that cometh]
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
The or that coming man, who or whatsoever he be, noted by an emphaticall article, Quam pulchrum est digito monstrari dicier hic est: What a blessed thing is it to be pointed out with the finger who shall be welcome to Christ: and with such a facil, and low condition or note: namely coming; The Gospel definition of the weakest true faith, Mat. 11.28. Come unto me all ye that labour and a • e heavy laden, &c. Heb. 7.25. He will save to the utmost them that come to God by him, Rev. 22.17. Let him that is a thirst come, and whosoever will come. So here, Him that cometh will I in no wise cast out; A lively proof that by comming, Christ means beleeving is Ioh. 7.37.38. v. 37. If any thrist let him come, and v. 38. He that beleeve • h on me out of his belly shall slow rivers. He saith, not him that beleeveth in expresse termes, as namely faith in all its latitude, (which is strong as well as weake,) and including all its acts which sometimes exults, as well as adhers; least thus he should have amazed a poore sinner, that but now is turning the first looke towards Christ, moving the first step towards Christ: but names the lowest act of faith, that he is some how nestling towards Christ. Christ saith not him that is running, for that imports speed and clearenesse in beleeving and moving towards Christ, which many a poore sinner hath not in a long time. He saith not Him that is skipping, which imports joy and triumph; which are hid from many a poore soule most of his life time. But him that is coming, though but tumbling in the dust of his owne unworthinesse, rowling on Gods footstoole the earth towards the throne of grace, (as faith, yea the faith of Christ is described, Psal. 22.8.In the Hebrew it is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Rowle, & it's sp • ken of Christ in his agony or desertion on the Crosse, Psa. 22.1, 2. &c. yet called saith
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Mat. 27.42. And therefore likely h • re R • wling is by our Tra • slators r ••• red
• rusting. ) Him that is coming, though lamenting, doubting, disputing, but coming; there are some things, some actings of faith of adherence and recumbence, though yet not of assurance.

Adde this [Him that cometh] is but in the participle, viz coming, and that too of the present tence or time, now coming, the first noting continuance of motion, and not to give a start forward, and then goe backe, as ver. 66. after the Text. But is still coming onwards towards Christ; he is rowling towards Christ, (as Christ in his desertion towards God, Psal. 22.) though not yet rested on Christ. The second noting his instantaneous and presentnesse of spirit now at the first reall discoveries of Christ that he cannot come too soone, before Christ is ready and willing to receive him. Adde, that it is spoken in the singular number, and of a single person.

In the former part of the verse, the expression is a Nowne of multitude, and in a most collective way, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) all, as if all things, or (as Marke 16.15.) every creature, that the Father giveth me, shall come to me; but here in the Text the expression intimates a single person. So that though our poore lonely person in a place, come towards Christ, he comes not by example in in the crowd, as others in this chapter; yea though they dishearten him, yet he hearkens to Christ; he thinkes to find favour with Christ, though others will not countenance him in it: this is according to Christs minde and heart, he will bid him welcome. Him, that is never so lonely, wondred at of all his neighbours, if he make towards me, he will in no wise refuse.

Yea, note further, that the expression, him that cometh, is every way indefinite; as it is not expressely universall, so it is not explicitly particular, Obiect. but left unlimited. But you will object, that it is limited in the beginning of the verse, saying, All that the Fatber giveth me, shall come unto me. So that none can come but whom the Father giveth; Now it is a question, whether the Father hath given me to Christ, and so whether ever he will give Christ to me? Answ. To which a word now, more anon, that this doth no more import any limitation in Gods mind, in regard of election, then in the Text of Gods promulgation, and offer of Christ to thee. For as this offer of Christ is expressed indefinitely in the T • xt, so also is election expressed indefinitely in the Context: All that the Father giveth, and so thou hast no more warrant to exclude thy selfe from the one, then from the other;
when God doth expresse no exclusion of thee from either. Yea, thou hast reason to include thy selfe within the election, when thou commest to Christ, upon this or the like promulgation. For thou hast here a demonstration that thou art elected, because thou comest. As Christ intends to prove that these Jewes that refuse Christ, are not elected because they come not. If thou come saith Christ, I shall in no wise cast thee out: therefore thou art one of the elect. It being a sure signe of one within the election, that he is taken, affected and drawne with the doctrine os election, to venter his soule upon it, as others now in heaven have done; and this perswasion drawing him saveable, to Christ to be saved; the conclusion in the Text is beyond all peradventure, That Christ will not cast such a soule off, no by no meanes; as it followes.

In no wise] The Greeke, for emphasis and vehemency of expression, to import the certainty of the thing, and the affection of Christ, useth two negatives,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (as the best French translate Ne point,) as we say in English, No by no meanes. It is usuall with God-Christ when he speakes of some great thing to men; that it may not seeme to be too good to be true, that he use more then one negative, in Text two, in Heb. 13:5. The last clause, I will not forsake thee, is in the Greeke, as in the Text, with a double negative,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
I will by no meanes forsake thee;
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . yea in that fift verse and the whole of the latter part are five negatives in the Greek, as if he should say, I will not, not leave thee, yea I will not, not, not forsake thee. Christ like a true hearted woer makes many promises in one full sentence, in one breath, that he will be faithfull to the soule. He will not, he will not (as it followes)

Cast out] who ever comes, comes by the Fathers power, Compare. ver. 44. so in the Context, therefore the Sonne will not take upon him the authority to cast him out. The Father sends him, therefore the Sonne in love to the Father, cannot find in his heart to refuse him. He that comes is a gift of the Father, bestowed on Christ, therefore Christ cannot but accept. He will not cast out, that is, he also will receive him in. As by the Fathers donation sent to Christ, so by Christs acceptation taken into himselfe and into the Church into mysticall union. And all this Christ protesteth in the future
tense, Bez. Piscat. or time, and that indicatively, though some read it potentially, and as in the present tense, I may by no meanes cast out: And th • reason of this varying is because the body of the Greeke word in the present time and the future in subjunct▪ mood is all one. [ 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ] the difference is onely in the Accent (a late invention) 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is in the present time. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is in the future, but more safe to take it in the future tense, (as the Syriac doth 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 I will not cast out, and the best French translate it ne i etteray point, I will in no case cast out.) For Christs words import, those that are coming to him from time to time in succeeding ages: and therefore must make the plaister commensurate to the soare. Besides the future tense is comprehensive, and includes all tenses,That which will or shall be must needs include is or hath beene. which is the reason why the Holy Ghost so often useth in the Old-Testament, the future time, for the past or present. And as thus Christ engageth himselfe for time, so for degree: he would not cast him out and out: So the Greeke 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Though Christ may cast him out of helpe sometime: yet not out and out not out of helpe and out of hope too. Though out of deliverance, yet not out of support too. Though out of sence and feeling of Christs power in him, yet not out of Christs safety and preservation of him. Christ will hold the child whiles it doth cry, till it sucke and be stilled.

So that all things considered, we have cleare-footing for this summary position touching Christs offer of himselfe to sinners, That Christ doth most freely and fully hold forth himselfe to receive his, and not cast out any that come to him. The maine Proposition. Freely, in regard of affection, Fully, in regard of his expression, will in no wise. Our Saviour seemes to speake in opposition to the manner of the Jewes, who for a trifle would cast out a man; yea for wel-doing, John 9.35. But saith Christ, I will in no wise cast out any commers to me. Or in way of intimation of a reproofe of the world, that cast out the Saints names for naught, Luke 6.22. But (saith Christ) I will in no wise cast out them that come. Or by way of aggravation of the sinne of the Jewes in neglecting Christ, that they perished voluntarily, if not obstinately, John 5.39, 40.

div.head: CHAP. II. Christs free and full offer of himselfe to fainting sinners, by foure Votes of Scripture duely extended, each harmoniously clearing the other, and all sweetly cheering the doubting soule.
div.p: THis sole-soule-saving point of Christs free and full offer of himselfe to sinners is much darkened by the doctrines of men, and dedignified by the doubting soules that are invited by it; and therefore much is spoken for it in the Scripture; especially four scriptures fully vote it a law for faith: (as evermore Christ is most tender of his tender ones to repeate and inculcate comfort for them, under the notions of heavy, laden, Mat. 11.28. Hungerers, Mat. 5. Bruised reedes, Mat. 12. Lambes, John 21.15.) I say four Scriptures most amply inact and set forth this Proposition of Christs offer of himselfe, as the onely law of faith.
1 Script. John 3.7, 8. Jesus stood and cried, saying, If any man thirst, let him come to me, and drinke: He that beleeveth on me, out of his belly shall flow rivers.
2 Script. Rev. 22.17. Let him that is a thirst, come, and whosoever will let him take of the water of life freely.
3 Script. The Text, John 6.37. Him that cometh to me, I will in no wise cast out.
4 Script. Isai. 55.1. Ho every one that thirsteth, come ye to the waters, and he that hath no money, come ye, buy and eate, yea come buy wine, and milke, without money and without price.

We have ordered them for a poore soules best advantage. For, as all the places have the same expression come: and the first place expounds both what is coming, v • z. at most beleeving with the least true faith, and what a • e the waters, namely Christ; So they all have some peculiar expressions to explaine, and cleare one another, and doe lye in a just method: The second to answer for the first: The third for the second, &c.
The first place proclaimes, If any man thirst, let him come to Christ, &c.
Object. Saith the distressed soule; I dare not, or doe not thirst, at least as I should.
Answ. Therefore the second place Revel. 22.17. proclaimes, whosoever will, let him come and take of the water of life freely: It addes a Quicunque vult, a whosoever will, to explaine thirst.
Object. But saith the poore selfe-vilifying sinner; I have no will, I rather feare then hope in coming.

Answ. Therefore the third Scripture, the Text John 6.37. proclaimes, That every one that comes, whether voluntate plena, or semi-plena, whether with a will, or an unwilling will, (like the Merchants will to throw his goods into the tempestuous sea to save his life,) so as he comes after Christ, though feare puts in the caveat, if he may be so bold, and some doubting puts in a Quaere, whether so great a sinner may lay claime, him will Christ Jesus in no wise cast out.
Object. But saith the sinner poore in spirit, unbottomed utterly from himselfe: I cannot come: I have no power, no grace, nothing; I stand so as to looke on, but cannot come.

Answ. Therefore the fourth Scripture Isai. 55.1. proclaimes, And he that hath no money: come ye and buy: come eate: come buy wine and milke, (cherishment and nourishment,) without money, and without price: without money, or monyes-worth.
Quest. But how can one be said to buy without any thing?

Answ. (As Aug. excellently,) the meaning is, Sell thy selfe, thine owne wit, reason, selfe-worth: Part with thy selfe, and that is all Christ desires. Say not thou art unworthy, (which implies thou lookest for a worthynesse in thy selfe,) Christ dyed for ungodly, for sinners, for enemies, Rom. 5. Say not thou canst not see any reason, why Christ should save thee, (which imports as if thou wouldst make faith to be grounded on humane reason, or that thou wouldest Arminian-like reason thy self into faith,) for if any man will be wise, he must become a foole, that he may be wise, 1 Cor. 3.18. Faith and fight are opposite, 2 Cor. 5.7. We must rest upon this, that Gods thoughts are above our thoughts, Isaiah 55.8, 9.

Thus these four places answer for one another, and to the perplexed sinner, unto full satisfaction in the thing, if the soule
be not at present taken and satisfied; which must be Gods inward worke, upon a soules waiting on God, for which there is a sure promise, Isai. 55:10. And it is a close of an answer to many scruples of the doubting sinner: As the raine comes downe from heaven, and returneth not thither, but watereth the earth, and makes it bring forth: so shall my word be; that is, my answers, for satisfaction of thy doubts, at last shall effectually satisfy thee.
I say thus these foure places cleare each other. Yea each place of these foure is wise enough to answer for it selfe.
The first place, John 7.35. saith, Every one that is thirsty, let him come.
If it be objected, by the poore soule, he cannot be thirsty as he would.

Ans. This place answereth, that by thirst, it means the lowest single desire of Christ, namely to be sensible of ones neede of Christ. For first it is spoken to the Jewes that came to the feast, rested in the Jewish ceremonies, Jer. 7:4. or at most in searching the Scriptures, John 5:39, 40. But not on Christ, and therefore called those that were righteous in their owne eyes, justifiers of themselves, such as neede no repentance; that is, in their owne opinion. Therefore thirst here signifies in the lowest step; a needinesse of Christ. Secondly, Thirsting, and coming are put together: so that such a desire as moves on from ones former standing still, towards Christ must needes be here included.

The sinne of presumption, yea the sinne against the Holy Ghost doth not exclud a man from salvation, as sins, but as they are such sinnes, as thinke they have no neede of Christ. One would thinke indeede that despaire were sensible enough of a neede of Christ; but this sinne is such a sinne as doth unChrist Christ; Though the despairer neede somewhat to save him, yet he doth not thinke Christ to be sufficient: but counts his guilt to be greater then Christs merit and efficacy. Therefore despairing Traitor Judas perished: when as the coming crucifiers, that came toward Christ by the preaching of Peter were saved, Acts 2.
The s • cond place, Rev. 22:17. Whos •• ver will, let him come.
If it be objected by the poore soule, he hath no will.

This place answers that voluntas semiplena est voluntas, an halfe will, an incompleate will, an unwilling will, is a will, for as it nils, so it wils too, Rom. 7:15. That which I doe I allow not, but what I would that doe I not: Yea God rich in mercy is sometimes pleased to entertaine any instinct or inclination in a man, by which he comes and lookes towards Christ, though for present, being dimme, he lookes to him sinistrously. As when sometimes a man goes to a Sermon to heare the word of Christ; but can hardly give himselfe a distinct account: why? He hath a mind to goe, and yet he is about to stay, and yet at last he goes, and yet is something unwilling while he goes, (as Israel went out of Egypt, but unwillingly, if we looke on all passages.) The soule perhaps goes to a Sermon at first, rather nilling something that is not Christ, (yet such as Christ must remove,) as disgrace of sinne, the horror of conscience, or &c. then distinctly willing Christ. (As a mayde gives her consent to a wooer, to be rid of a worse, rather then for love of him as yet,) so that a man sometimes comes to an ordinance, (and so somewhat towards Christ,) rather by a common providence, or by occasions; then by a distinct, entire, morall act of his owne will. Augustine went (as he confesseth) to heare Ambrose his eloquence of words, but is catcht with the power of his matter. So that I say God rich in mercy, is sometimes pleased to entertaine a meane will, cherish that inclination which can hardly be called a morall act of the will: so that according to interpretation by divine providence whomsoever will, may signifie, but as much as quemlibet, whomsoever, any how coming, neerer towards Christ where he will be found Marke 16:15. Preach the Gospell to every creature; be his will, more or lesse; direct, or indirect and oblique.
The third place, John 6:37. Him that comes, &c.
If the poore soule object, he cannot come.

This place answers that all coming must be included, though yet he cannot move with a distinct act of faith; for till Christ doth radiat on the soule, there is no act of seeing: nor can he yet labour spiritually for Christ. For he cannot make bricks till straw be given him: But he comes to an ordinance, & becomes a waiter on this ordinance: he lookes towards a Saviour in an ordinance,
by that common knowledge he learnes at an ordinance. As many looked to the brazen serpent, who at first had not faith to be healed. If Christ must looke on converted Peter, before he can repent of that particular failing in denying his Master, then sure Christ must looke on unconverted Paul, before he can beleeve.
The fourth place, Isai. 55.1. He that hath no money, nor price, let him come and buy: let him sell himselfe, and he shall buy Christ.
If the poore soule object here, that he a poore non-convert cannot sell himselfe, part with his owne wit, reason and seeming righteousnesse, &c.

This place answers, First, That he may legally, though not evangelically: As thirst imports in part a heat & drought of the soule by the doctrine of the fiery law Deut. 32.2. as the Scriptures call it. Secondly, That by attending to the doctrine of the Gospell, he shall be wrought to an evangelicall thirst after Christ. That is, this text and the like propounding Christ in his excellencies, as under the notions of milke, wine, fatnesse, and dainties, they shall make the palat or mouth of the poore soule water after Christ, for his lovelynesse sake. So that as thirst makes thee come: so he that propounds Christ to the thirsty will make thee thirst.

So that we conclude with this generall answer for all the foure places joyntly drawne out of them. That as all these places are Christs word: so they import that this Doctor or Teacher of the Churches must be he that workes in his Disciples or Scholars to thirst, to will, to come, to sell ones selfe. For grace is wrought by the word. Faith comes by hearing. The word is the word of life. While Peter spake these words, the Holy Ghost fell on them all which heard, Acts 10.44. So that Christ that makes these conditions, makes thee so conditioned, Phil. 2.13. For it is God that worketh in you to will and to doe of his good pleasure. Whiles he preacheth the condition, he makes the impression: when by common preparing grace, Christ makes thee coming off of thy selfe, he is coming towards thee; Christ approaching, thou art made to be effectually coming.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the proportion and equall latitude of Election, and Redemption.
div.p:
FOr further clearing of what hath beene said, thi Question would be solved, whether Election and Redemption are not some-how opposite? for election is exprest but of some, redemption is offered to all. To which we answer, though we toucht it afore. That though redemption it selfe, be in the first act larger then election: viz. in Christ drying in the common nature of man, not in that of Angels, & thereby brings humane nature nearer to salvation, then the common nature of all Angels; so that mans nature in generall, is saveable, whereas wicked Angels are not (For verely he tooke not on him the nature of Angels, hut he tooke on him the Seede of Abraham, Heb. 2.16. which is but the renewing of that covenant with Adam, Gen. 3.15.) For otherwise men under the Gospell, could not be justly damned for unbeliefe, but would be threatned for not beleeving a ly, namely that Christ died for them, when as in no sort he did. But this distinction of Christs dying for the common nature, solves that difficulty, shewes what interest all men have in Christs redemption, and the fault of them to whom it is made knowne, in not claiming it and closing with it: I say though in this first act, redemption seemes of a greater latitude then election, yet in the last and ultimate act they are equall; which last act is to make particular persons, (that are onely saveable in in the common nature,) to be actually saved in their particular persons: which is done by Christ speciall act of mediatourship, viz. intercession, John 17.20. I pray for them which shall beleeve on me: whereas the other of saveablenesse is done by Christs common act of mediatorship of making attonement by death. Rom. 5.8, 9, 10. So that evenly to an haire those onely that are elected, are actually redeemed. For though in Gods election there be no necessity of compulsion: yet there is in it a necessity of infallibility; of infalibility else God should not know what would befall his owne purposes.
Yet not of compulsion; and therefore we must not charge that upon election which belongs not to it. As that non-election doth effect and force us out of salvation. We must not confound Gods decree, and the execution of his decree, or cut off the rest of the links of Gods predestination, namely vocation, justification, conformation to Christ, &c. Rom. 8. from the first act of Election choosing of some, and so on the contrary. For non-election cannot dammne us, unlesse we refuse vocation, &c.

And as thus, election and redemption in themselves, in the thing, are of equall latitude, so also in the promulgation or off • r in the Doctrine of the Gospell. The Gospell holding out election indefinitly to us, (though determinated with God,) The Lord knoweth them that are his, 2 Tim. 2.19. And that THEM, to be a great many, though defines not to us how many: of J • ws, 144000. (a certaine number for an uncertaine,) but of all Jews and Gentiles, a great multitude which no man could number, Revel. 7.4.9. And redemption indefinitely that Christ died for ungodly, for sinners, for enemies. For men voide of grace, ordinary sinners, and extraordinary, that had opposed him, Rom. 5.

So that as redemption under an indefinite notion is offered to all, so election is held forth under the same notion to all, especially to all to whom the doctrine of these doth come: So that as faith must looke to the indefinite promise of redemption, so love must looke to the indefinite expression of Gods election. Men must throw themselves downe under the indefinite expression of election, lye under the beames of the doctrine thereof, to see if it beget a loving opinion in them, that God is willing to save sinners, (and so them) having purposed it from all eternity: and throw themselves under the powerfull sound of the promises of redemption, to waite till they worke a beleeving perswasion, that God hath actually redeemed them: therefore thoughts of election, if right thoughts, doe not beate a soule off from redemption, but makes way, and puts him on, being the foundation of all. And who ever hath the first, hath the last, or hath the last, hath the first. And though neither of them are absolutely of all; yet their indefinite doctrine and tender should in our eye that live under the Gospell, seeme
more wishly to looke towards, and intend us (unlesse we refuse) and to conceive more rationally, that the non-elect, and non-redeemed are those to whom the Gospell never came, or was never by them entertained. For God hath not expressely excluded, nor doth he utterly cast thee off, till thou cast him off, 2 Chron. 36.15, 16. They mocked the messengers of God, and despised his word, till the wrath of the Lord came upon them, and there was no remedy, Prov. 29.1. He that being often reproved hardened his necke, shall come to destruction without remedy. And in the New-Testament onely for the sinne of refusing Christ all along is damnation pronounced, unpardonablenesse pronounced. Thou oh man demurrest about Gods decree, and reprobation, but who gave thee leave to meddle with the secret things of God: heare his revealed things which he saith belongs to thee; God doth not actually cast thee off beyond all remedy, till thou actually cast off him; and so casts thee off, not for originall sinne, but actuall sinne, and that to not for every actuall sinne, but for those that cast off the remedy, namely the word of Christ, and Christ the word.

div.head: CHAP. IIII. The bottome dived into: Christs heart looked into, for security to a poore soule, that Christ can find in his heart thus freely and fully to offer himselfe to him.
div.p: THus we have presented you with high expressions of Christs good will to sinners: but because man as man, is hardly drawne to be confident on bare dictates of words; we dare referre the point to the dint of divine reason.

First, Christ is God, therefore most naturally good: goodnesse is his essence, mercy, compassion, &c. His essence, Christ is God, therefore infinitely good: he cannot be God, and be limited of goodnesse: because good therefore communicative of
himselfe: first, because naturally good, therefore his offer of himselfe to doe good to a sinner is free, Psal. 119. Thou art good, and dost good. And Rom. 3.24. Being justified freely by his grace. Things and persons of the noblest natures are most freely bountifull of themselves. The Sunne to communicate light, and life to the world, men of great birth and breeding of a free,2 Sam. 24.23. franke spirit, like Araunah: therefore the Hebrew word
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 liberaliter ad dandum moveri 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 voluntarius, liberalis, munificus, princeps. that signifies a noble man, signifies free, or voluntary, or bountifull. God is essentially that of which there is but an impresse upon the creature. And because Christ as God is good enough of himselfe, he for his part needs no causes from the creature, to pump up & draw out his goodnesse: Christ will be sought unto that men may owne his goodnesse, Ezek. 36. John 14.13, 14. But it was of Christs goodnesse to promp us with this rule: and when he suckles us, he gives the milke of the breasts of consolation freely himselfe, Isai. 66.11, 12. Secondly, because Christ as God is infinitely good, therefore the offer of himselfe is full. The sea being full of water, streames in fountaines, Eccles. 1. and flowes in rivers, offering it selfe to the adjacent Countries.

Secondly, Christ is Jesus, a Saviour: so called and anointed, that he might save his people from their sinnes, Matth. 1.21. As he will answer to his name, will not betray his trust, be faithfull to him that put him in trust with the office of mediatorship, he must save them his Father gives him to save: So it immediately followes the Tex, as arguing the assertion of the Text. Those that come to me, I will in no wise cast out, for I came downe from heaven, not to doe mine owne will, but the will of him that sent me: and this is the will of him that sent me, that every one that seeth the Sonne, and beleeveth on him, may have everlasting life. So that if it were possible, that Christ did not love us, but loved the Father onely to be obedient unto him that loveth us; this would be sufficient to offer himselfe to comfort us. So Christ argue • , John 16.26, 27. I say not I will pray the Father, for the Father himselfe loveth you. So that if Christ love the Father, and the Father us: he will for the Fathers sake doe any thing for us.

Thirdly, Christ as God and man must needes aime at his owne
and his Fathers glory. The salvation of man is great. A soule is more worth then a world: therefore great is Gods glory in saving a soule, 1 Cor. 1. two last. Now as God is infinite in lovelynesse, so Christ as God must needs infinitely love himselfe, and as man love his father: and therefore must needs be full, yea infinite in desire to advance the glory of the God-head: and so must needs be free & full in his offer to promote that advancing Gods honor.

div.head: CHAP. V. Untill men come to Christ by faith, they are out of Christ, unreconciled to God, and not justified, contrary to the doctrine of eternall justification, as it is held forth by some.
div.p:
FRom the main position before laied downe, we are instructed and informed, that till men according to the sence of the Text, come to Christ, and are received into Christ by the spirit of faith, they are without Christ, yea without God, yea many wayes without, John 5.39, 40. Ye search the Scriptures, (for so it should be read indicatively, not imperatively:) For in them ye thinke to have eternall life, and (indeed saith Christ,) they are they that testifie of me, and (or but) ye will not come unto me, (that is by faith,) that ye might have life; so Ephes. 2.12. That in times past ye were without Christ, being aliens from the Commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenant of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world. And therefore God cannot be actually reconciled to them that are not in Christ by faith. For within and without cannot be all one. But (saith the Text) men are without till they come to Christ by faith: when they come by faith, so in that they shall not be cast out. So that place of Ephes. 2.12. Having teld them, ver. 8. Ye are saved by grace through faith, he addes in the 12 verse, that formerly afore Christ came, they were without Christ, and so without God, and shewes how, viz. being strangers from the covenant of promise, the Ground of faith. If God hath decreed, that Christ dwels in us by faith, Ephes. 3. That we are justified by faith, Rom. 4. Rom. 5.
Then that decree of God must be executed ere we can be saved; and therefore we are not to rest and relye on Gods bare decree. For as God doth not decree contradictions, namely, for a man to be within and without in the same instant, in the same respect: Reconciliation or justification being that same WITHIN; and not to be in Christ by faith is to be WITHOUT. So twise together, Rom. 8.29, 30. Whom he foreknew he predestinated to be made conformable to his Son; whom he predestinated, them he called: whom he called, them also he JƲSTIFIED. So that if God himself doth not rest satisfied in a meer purpose without performance, then may not we rest in Gods meer purpose of reconciliation, without his act in & through Christ. As God is actually offended with sin, so there must be actuall reconciliation, in the actuall death of Christ, actually ours, by actuall faith. Else why is it said, Joh. 3. last, He that beleeveth not the Son, shall not see life: but the wrath of God abides on him. Tis true that Gods purpose is an act of Gods minde in himself, but not an action upon his creature without him: no more then purpose of creation is creation. Or else you must say the world was actually eternall, and not created in the beginning. So that as actuall creation is not eternall; so nor actuall reconciliation, or justification: there being no more of this eternall, then the act of Gods purpose, in time to justifie. Yet this argues no alteration in God, being onely the progression and proceeding of his unchangeable purpose, to effect according to that purpose. Which purpose is not (in Gods ordinarie way) performed without many actions to be done in time. 1. Creating or generating man, by his speciall concurrence, especially in regard of the soul. Psal. 102.18. 2. Preserving man till he grow up to a perfect understanding. 3. Teaching him by his word. So that to rest for justification in Gods meer purpose, were to make void most of Gods actions, and ordinances. But to perceive Gods actuall entring into atonement with us in the application of Christ, is to see our selves exceedingly more engaged to God in love, praise and dutie; as well for his actions upon us, and in us, as for his purpose towards us.

div.head: CHAP. VI. A man is justified by faith. Contrary to Samuel Richardson his opinion, denying faith to have any thing to do in our justification; In his book, entitled, JƲSTIFICATION BY CHRIST ALONE. Printed by M. S. 1647.
div.p:
IT follows also from that text, Joh. 6.3. and the main Position thence inferred, that faith hath an hand in receiving Christ, and being received into Christ; and consequently according to the many expresse votes of the Scriptures, hath an hand in our justification. As, Phil. 3.9. And be found in him, (that is, in Christ) not having mine own righteousnesse, which is of the Law, but that which is through faith, (THE, is not in the originall) of Christ, the righteousnesse which is of God by faith. Twise, you see, it is expressed, that we have righteousnesse by means of faith in two severall expressions, viz: By faith, and through FAITH of Christ, or concerning Christ, that procured that righteousnesse, we apply by faith. Rom. 3.28. Therefore we conclude, a man is justified by faith, without the works of the Law. Now the works of the Law are not opposite to Christ as in him. For Christ fulfilled the works of the Law for us (as the Scriptures frequently tell us) but in us, the works of the Law are opposite to faith in point of justification. And therefore it is said, we are justified by faith, beleeving that Christ satisfied the Law for us, that we might be justified gratis, as it is in that 3d. to Rom. v. 24. Being justified freely by his grace, through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus. Christ payed a price of redemption for it. But we have it freely. Gal. 2.16. Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the Law, but by faith of Jesus Christ, (no article in the Greek to intimate any THE). Faith of Christ or, (which is all one) beleif of Christ (crediting his promises, and resting in his satisfaction) signifies beleeving into Jesus Christ, as it follows in this verse. Even as we have beleeved in Jesus Christ, (Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. INTO) that we might be
justified, BY FAITH of Christ, (so the Greek) that is, by faith, concerning, in, upon into Christ, as is aforesaid. Gal. 3.8, 9, 11, 13, 14. read the place, and ponder it. As also, Rom. 4. throughout the whole Chapter, giving instances in Abraham and David; that justification is by faith. Upon which the Apostle infers in the next Chap. Rom. 5.1. Being justified by faith, we have peace with God. So that vain is the shift of the Adversaries to this Doctrine to say, that the point in that place, Rom. 5.1. should be removed thus: Being justified, by faith we have peace. For the other pointing thus, Being justified by faith, we have peace, doth directly answer to the Apostles dispute in the former Chapter. Besides what peace doth faith bring, but the peace of justification. It first layes hold on justification, or it can speak no peace. Lastly, that pointing, Being justified by faith, to be the right, is put out of all doubt in those places before quoted in Rom. Galat. &c. where the Apostle having largely disputed the point of justification, makes it his great conclusion, that a man is justified by faith.
Obj. Say the Adversaries: The whole work of our salvation was accomplished upon the Crosse.

Answ. Not his resurrection. Yet he arose for our justification. Not his intercession, yet by that we are saved: Heb. 7.25. And to the point in hand. Though on the Crosse he paid the price of our redemption; yet, Joh. 17.20. he prayed that we might beleeve. Subordinate things are not contrary, but subservient. It is true, the Carpenter built the house, but it is as true, that he built it with his ax, saw, hammer, and other tools. It is certain that James payed such moneys to John; but then it is as certain, John received that money. Sure we are, Christ dyed for our justification; but it is as sure, that we are justified by faith in the death of Christ. Christ payed the price of our debt to God the Father on the Crosse. But the assignment of it to us as payed for us is by faith; as is the meaning of the Scriptures, saying, we are justified by faith.

We say not we are justified by faith as it is a qualitie. So it is sanctification. Gal. 5.22. And we are not justified by holinesse. Nor by it as a meer act, a working qualitie; so we
should be justified by a work. By somewhat we do. Nor by faith, as meerly appointed and instituted of God for that end, as to be an instrument in our justification. For then God should justifie us without reall amends to his justice. He should pay himself really offended, with an opinion that faith of it self should repay him. But we say, that we are justified by faith as an hand taking Christ. It is not the hand of it self justifies, but Christ in the hand.
Qu. Doth not then sanctification in order of nature go before justification; Faith being a grace of sanctification?

Answ. Our notion of it, with submission to more light, when it shall be discovered is this. That Christ having payed for our justification in suffering for us, he comes with his Spirit, and represents the same in an immediate thought put upon our spirits by his Spirit, that this satisfaction of Christ is ours, and after that in order of nature created that thought into a standing permanent habit of faith.
But to return to the opposers of justification by faith. They object, Its said by Christ on the Crosse▪ It is finished.
Ans. The paying is finished, not the praying. Heb. 7.25. That he doth yet continually; part of which intercession is that we may beleeve. Joh. 17.
Obj. Where ever it is said, we are justified by faith, by faith is understood Christ.
Ans. This is not so. Witnesse Phil. 3.9. Gal. 2.16. Gal. 3.14. where there is mention of Christ and faith too, as both concurring in our justification.

To conclude. Sure the opposers of justification do think, at least in part, that we are justified by faith; because they are ever and anon upon severall occasions readie to say so in effect. Witnesse these expressions in the book called [Justification by Ch • ist alone, by S. R.] namely, p. 8. Jesus Christ by once offering the sacrifice of himself on the Crosse put an end to sin. O what a fountain of consolation is here to all THAT BELEIVE. Who now may say, once sin was mine, then it was layed on Christ, and NOW they are neither mine nor his; and NOW Christs righteousnesse is mine. P. 9. Faith is given us, that by it we may live
out of our selves in another, even the Lord Jesus, &c. P. 10. Christs RESƲRRECTION doth declare us to be just who BELEEVE in him. P. 15. The elect are visibly in their sins till they BELEEVE. See more of this, of the interest of faith in Justification in the Antidote to Antinomianisme. To which the Author never replyed that I know. But Mr. Richardson did endevour it a little at the end of his said Book [Justification by Christ alone.] But so slenderly, in the judgement of the ordinarie Readers, as hath been confessed to me by them, that I omit to make any Duply or Answer to them.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Vntill men come to Christ by faith, they have not actually any saving benefit by Christs death. Where is stated and discussed the Question about Ʋniversall Redemption, of the true intent and extent thereof.
div.p:
TO further clear our in-being in Christ, this Question must be handled. Two extreames of opinions there are about the extent and intent of Christs death and satisfaction, that widen the difference. Which we shall now speak to (as God shall assist) for the clearing of the point in hand; and I shall not be wholly singular, but keep company with some late learned. The one extreame of opinion extendeth and violently stretcheth the death and satisfaction of Christ so much too far, as that it thinks that thereby God for his part is actually reconciled to all men, and doth really discharge every man living from all his sins, and that before faith comes. Onely they confesse, that they for their parts perceive not that benefit by it, whiles they have no faith to beleeve that God doth so love them. Now from this extreame opinion it would follow, that God should be actually reconciled to man before he did put on Christ; And that God should forgive a mans sins (which is justification) before he beleeved. Whereas the very elect themselves before their effectuall calling
are said to be a people not beloved. Rom. 9.25. And whiles they are without Christ to be without hope; as we heard afore out of Ephes. 2.12.

The other extreame opinion contracteth the riches of Christs satisfaction into too narrow a compasse, as if none had any interst any way therein, but such as were elected from the foundation of the world, though by the Gospel every one be charged to receive the same. Now from this extreame it would follow, that a man under the Gospel should be bound in conscience to beleeve that which is untrue, and charged to take and receive that with which he hath nothing to do, namely, to beleeve, and take Christ as dying for him, when as Christ did not dye for him; nor did he belong to Christ in that respect.
Some, to take away this difficultie, answer thus. That it follows onely from this argument, that some under the Gospel are bound to beleeve an impossible thing.

Ans. This solves not the knot. For, 1. I ask, will God condemne a soul for not beleeving that which is impossible to be had? 2. Why, say I, is it impossible for them to have Christ, but because as these men say, Christ never intended, or extended his death so far?

Others answer to this difficultie thus. That though under the Gospel that shall never have Christ, are not bound by the voice of the Gospel to beleeve that Christ dyed for them; nor are they condemned for not beleeving that Christ dyed for them.

Answ. The contrary seems to be evident, Joh. 3.16. God so loved the WORLD, that he gave his onely begotten Son, that whosoever beleeveth IN HIM should not perish. Greek, INTO HIM. and v. 18. He that beleeveth on him, Gr. INTO HIM, is not condemned: but he that beleeveth not is condemned already, because be hath not beleeved IN (Gr. INTO) the name of the onely begotten Son of God. See how God, 1. propounds his Son more generally, as sent to the WORLD, and as it is in v. 17. He sent not his Son into the WORLD to condemne the world, but that the WORLD might be saved. Then, 2. requires men particularly
to beleeve IN or INTO his Son: as HE that beleeveth in him, &c. Therefore to avoid both these rocks, the word of truth, by which faith is begotten, Ephes. 1.13. must be sought into, to finde a middle way, wherein to go safely, and not to split against either of the said two rocks of ab • urdities.

For the better and readier finding out this middle and safer way, we must be carefull in the businesse of our redemption, cleerly to distinguish between the satisfaction of Christ, absolutely considered, and the application of the same relatively to men in particular. The differences are; 1. That satisfaction absolutely considered, was once, and at once done for All; but the application of it to man, is still in doing. 2. Satisfaction absolutely considered, bringeth with it sufficiencie to discharge all mens whole debt; The application of it addes unto it efficiencie to make it effectuall. 3. The satisfaction of Christ makes the sins of mankinde onely pardonable, fit for pardon, else Gods justice could not put up the wrong done to him by sin. The particular application maketh the sins of those to whom it is applyed to be pardoned, actually and solemnly to be acquitted by pardon. So that in summe thus. Though all sins of all men are mortall in regard of the stipend due to them by the Law; yet all do not actually bring forth eternall death; because the gracious promise of the Gospel holding forth Christ inhibits, supercedes, and stayes the execution. So that all the sins of mankinde are become veniall in respect of the price payed by Christ unto his Father; so that in shewing mercie to all, if such were his pleasure, his justice should be no looser. But all do not obtain actuall remission of sin, because most offenders do not take out, nor plead their pardon, as they ought to do. Ezek. 36. For all this will I be sought unto. And Isa. 55. Call upon the Lord while he is neer: and then it follows, He will abundantly pardon. If Christ had not assumed our nature, and therein made satisfaction for the injurie offered by us to God, God would not have come to a treatie of peace with us, (as it is said, Isa. 1. Come now let us reason together,) no more then with the fallen Angels, whose nature his Son Christ did not assume: Hebr. 2. and so were finally rejected.
But this way being made through the flesh of Christ (as the Apostle speaks, Hebr. 10.20.) God holdeth out unto men the golden Scepter of his Gospel; and thereby not onely signifieth his pleasure of admitting them into his presence; and accepting their submission (which is a wonderfull grace, and favour) but also sendeth an embassage unto them, intreating them that they would be reconciled unto him. 2 Cor. 5.20.

Hence is inferred against the first extremitie of opinion (of which see before) that by vertue of Christs satisfaction in our nature, God is made appeasable unto our nature; but is not actually appeased towards any mans person, untill he hath received his Son, and put on him the Lord Jesus Christ.

Hence also is inferred against the 2d: extremitie of opinion (of which afore) that all may be said to have a common interest in the merits of Christ: howsoever all do not injoy the benefit thereof, because they do not take it. The well spring of life is set open to all, freely. Revel. 22.17. Wh • soever will, let him take of the water of life freely. But many fetch not, having nothing to draw with, and the Well is deep. Faith is the onely vessell whereby we are to draw all vertue from Christ; and that is to be fetched from the hearing of the word of truth, the Gospel of our salvation. Ephes. 1.13. Rom. 10. which holdeth forth this bottome for every one to build his faith upon, thus.
What Christ hath provided for me, and the Gospel offers to me, that I ought with all thankfulnesse to accept, and apply to my comfort.
But Christ by his death, and obedience, hath provided a sufficient remedie for the taking away of sin, and the Gospel offereth it.
Therefore I ought to accept it, and apply it to the comfort of mine own soul.

Now many hearing this Gospel of salvation, do either not regard it, or not beleeve it; or if in a sort beleeve it, that is the truth of it, yet imbrace it not; but are so wedded to their sins, that they have no desire to be divorced from them: and therefore neglect the taking to themselves, and applying to their own souls this gracious offer made unto them.

Notwithstanding which neglect on their parts, we may truly say, [That good things were provided for them on Christs part,] and that a rich price was put into the hand of a fool, howsoever he had no heart to use it: Prov. 17.16. Our Saviour by that which he performed on his part hath procured a jubilee for all the sons of Adam: Luk. 4.18, 19. And the Gospel is the trumpet whereby he doth proclaim libertie to the captives, and preacheth the acceptable yeer of the Lord. If (as Levit. 25.24. Exod. 21.5. Deut. 15.16.) for all this some are so well pleased with their captivitie, that they desire no deliverance; this derogateth nothing from the generalitie of the freedome annexed unto that YEER. If one say to his sin, or love of the world, his old master, I love thee, I will not depart from thee, I will not go out free, then he shall be (as the servants so saying in the aforesaid texts) bored in the ear for a slave; and serve for ever. But that slavish disposition of his, maketh the extent of the priviledge of that yeer not a whit the straighter; because he was included within the generall grant as well as others, howsoever he was not disposed to take the benefit of it. The King of heaven (saith our Saviour, Matth. 22.2.) is like unto a certain King that made a marriage, that is, a mariage feast, as the Syriack 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 signifies) for his Son, and sent forth his servants to those that were bidden to that marriage-feast with this message, [Behold I have prepared my dinner, my oxen, and fatlings are killed, and all things are readie, come to the wedding: v. 4.] But if we look to the event, They which were bidden made light of the invitation, and went their wayes, one to his farm, another to his merchandise: v. 5. yet this neglect of theirs doth nothing falsifie the word of the King which we have in the 4th. verse, namely, That the dinner was prepared, and those unworthy guests were hidden thereunto. For (saith the Apostle, Rom 3.4.) What if some did not beleeve? shall their unbelief disanull the faith and truth of God? God forbid. Yea let God be true, and every man a lyar: as it is written, That thou mayest be justified in thy sayings, and overcome when thou judgest. Just as the Lord speaketh by the Prophet, (Ezek. 18.29, 30.) Let not the house of Israel say, the way of the Lord is not equall. For when he cometh to judge them every one according to his wayes, Ezek. 33.
20. the inequalitie of the way will be found on their sides, and not on his. Oh house of Israel, are not my wayes equall; or are not your wayes unequall, saith the Lord. So in that Ezek. 18. The Lord is righteous in all his wayes, and holy in all his works. Psal. 145.17. All the wayes of the Lord are mercy and truth. Psal. 25.10. When we were in our sins, it was of his infinite mercie, that any remedie should be provided, for our recovery. And when the medicine is prepared, we are never the nigher to actuall salvation, unlesse he be pleased out of his free mercie to apply the same unto us; that so the whole praise of our redemption from the beginning to the end, may be intirely attributed to the riches of his mercie, and nothing may be left to sinfull flesh wherein to glory. The freeing of the people of the Jews from the captivitie of Babylon, (Isa. 45.1, &c.) was a type of Christs great deliverance of us wrought by him. Cyrus King of Persia (who was Christus Domini, the Christ, or the anointed of God, and herein but a type or shadow of him that is Christus Dominus, Christ the Lord, the author of our redemption) publisheth his generall proclamation in this manner, [Who is there among you of all the people? The Lord his God be with him, and let him go up. 1 Chron. 26.33.] Now it is true that they alone did follow this calling, whose spirit God had moved to go up. Ezra 1.5. But could they therefore, that remained still behinde in Babylon (1 Chron. 4.23.) justly plead that the Kings Grant was not large enough? or that they were excluded from going up, by any clause contained therein? Just so the matter of our redemption purchased by our Saviour Christ, lyeth open to all, all are invited to it, none that hath minde to accept it, is excluded from it. The beautifull feet of them that bring glad tydings of the Gospel of peace, do bring good news of great joy into every house wherein they tread. (Luk. 1.79 Luk. 10.5. Rom. 10.15.) The first part of their message being this, Peace be to this house. But unlesse God be pleased out of the abundance of his mercie to guide our feet into the way of peace, the rebellion of our nature is such, and so great, we run headlong into the wayes of destruction and misery, and the wayes of peace we do not know. (Rom. 3.16, 17. They have
not all obeyed the Gospel, saith the Apostle, Rom. 10.16. All are not apt to entertain the message of peace. And therefore though Gods Embassadors make a true tender thereof to all to whom they are sent, yet the peace rested only upon the sons of peace. But if they meet with such as will not listen to this motion, their peace doth return again unto themselves. Luk. 10.6. The proclamation of the Gospel, Rev. 22.17. runs thus: Let him that is athirst, come. For him this peace especially is provided, because none but he will take the pains to come. But lest we should think this did any way abridge the largenes of that offer, a Quieun{que} vult is added in these words: And whosoever will, let him come and take of the waters of life freely. Yet withall, we must hold this, That it is God that worketh in us to will and to do of his good pleasure. Phil. 2.13. And though the call be never so loud, and so large, yet no man can come effectually, except God the Father draw him: as it is Joh. 6.44. For the universalitie of the satisfaction, nothing derogateth from the necessity of Gods speciall grace in the application of it. Neither doth this specialtie of grace in the application any whit abrogate the generalitie of the satisfaction.
And therefore when men urge that argument out of Joh. 17.9. Christ PRAY'D not for the world, therefore he PAY'D not for the world; there are many considerable things may be replyed unto.

For the consequence may be excepted against upon many good reasons. For though Christ did not pray for the world, yet he might pay for the world. Because this paying is a more generall or common act, of satisfaction; his praying a more speciall and choice act of intercession: so that though both acts agree in this, that they be acts of Christs Priesthood, yet in other respects are widely distinguishable. 1. Paying, that is, giving satisfaction, doth properly give content to Gods justice (as hath been shewed); Praying, that is, intercession, doth solicite Gods mercy. 2. This paying satisfaction containeth a preparation of the plaister or potion necessarie for mans salvation; But praying by way of intercession, is the means of application of that remedie to the malady. 3. The paying satisfaction
belongs to the common nature of mankinde which Christ assumeth: when as praying intercession is a speciall priviledge vouchsafed to such particular persons onely as the Father hath given to his Son Christ.

And therefore I think we may safely conclude from all these premisses, That the Lamb of God offering up himself (cloathed with humane nature) a sacrifice for the sins of the whole world, intended by giving satisfaction sufficiently to Gods justice, to make the nature of man (which he assumed) saveable, a fit subject for mercy, and to prepare a soveraigne medicine for the sins of the whole world, which should be denyed to none that minde to take the benefit thereof; howsoever he intended not, by applying this all sufficient sacrifice, or satisfaction to every one in particular, to make it effectuall unto the salvation of all, or to procure thereby, at the hands of the Father, actuall pardon for the sins of the whole world. He applyes this onely effectually to them who making claim to the satisfaction, by promise suing for the spirit and faith upon other promises, in prayer waiting for a gracious return untill they have it. So that in one respect Christ may be said to dye for all: and in another respect, not to dye for all. Yet so as in respect of his merit, he may be accounted a kinde of universall cause of the restoring of our nature, as Adam was of the depraving of it. So that, to conclude, as far as I can discern one did curiously hit the nayl on the head,Mors Christi est quasi quaedam universalis causa salutis, sicut peccatum primi hominis fuit quasi universalis causa damnationis. Oportet autem universalem causam applicari ad unumquem{que} specialiter, ut effectum universalis causae ille percipiat Effectus peccati primi hominis pervenit ad unumquem{que} per carnis originem; effectus autem mortis Christi pertingit ad unumquem{que} per spiritualem regenerationem, per quam homo Christo quodamodo conjungitur, & incorporatur. when he determined this matter on this wise. The death of Christ is as it were a certain universall cause of salvation; as the sin of the first man was as it were an universall cause of damnation. But an universall cause must be applyed to every one in speciall, that he may partake of the effect of the universall cause. The effect of the sin of the first man came upon every man by the originall of corrupt flesh; and the effect of Christs death reacheth to every one (whom it reacheth) by spirituall regeneration, by which, man is after a sort conjoyned and incorporated to Christ. So he. We will onely adde this. That as the sin of Adam was an
universal cause of eternall death unto mankinde in generall; but not to every particular man, unlesse originall corruption were derived to him, as Christs humane nature in the very conception was exempted. So the satisfaction of Christs death is for all mankinde, but is not effectuall to any particular man, but to him to whom Christs grace is derived.

Upon all it follows. That though the fallen Angels have no encouragement at all to hearken to the Gospel, there being nothing at all for them: yet all men to whom the Gospel shall come, have much encouragement to hearken to it in this, That Christ took upon him the common nature of mankinde, made it saveable, brought it neerer to salvation then the nature of lapsed Angels. And more particularly that it is said indefinitely, Christ dyed for sinners, for ungodly, for enemies. And yet more particularly in the text, that him that cometh to him he wil in no wise cast out. I say they have encouragment to attend to the Gospel there to finde an effectuall testimony of Christs dying for them, by drawing them to beleeve it; and not to stand off, or fall on, upon notions of their own (of Christ dying FOR ALL, or if not for ALL, then NOT FOR ME) before we consult with the effectuall voice of the word of the Gospel. It is not left with, or to, or in our wit and endeavours to dispute our selves into Christ by syllogismes, yea groundlesse syllogismes, but we waiting on the Gospel Christ effectually draws us, and takes us into himself. Sure enough Christ dyed for that soul that hangs upon this breast of the Gospel without separation, that Christ dyed for sinners.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. No man living under the sound of the Gospel, can have any true and just reason of standing still, or standing off, from coming to Christ.
div.p:
IF Christ open his heart so freely, and spread his arms so wide, as to receive all •••• rs unto him; then why do not all
that hear this come to him? There are too many if God pleased (as we may say after the manner of men) left among the Heathens without the bounds of the Gospel, to perish as reprobates. We that are within the sound of such invitations, as the text, &c. should conclude, that they do as surely, and directly belong to us, as they are spoken to us. And that we are as clearly included within the generalitie of the propositions made to us; as undoubtedly they do not in the least expression exclude us. Why then should we exclude our selves? what can we scruple, or object, but here it is fully answered? Doest question whether thou mayest be so bold as to present thy self before Christ for mercie? lo Christ offers himself. The King woes the begger. We as embassadors for Christ, beseech you to be reconciled. 2 Cor. 5.20. Doest doubt whether he means thee? See Christ most fully holds forth himself to thee. As fully, as to the thousands of souls that are now in heaven by the same Gospel-promises. What shall I do more to my vineyard? We cannot prescribe what more God should say, and speak, so as to Juit with a speech made to all that ever shall hear the Gospel. But sayest thou, are there not conditions on my part, which I am not able to perform? No, it is said he holds forth himself most freely. If any condition be included in coming, he works it in the Ministery that bids us come. Its a Gospel-creating word. So all comes freely to us. You have beside the free consent of the Bridegrome, the Bride, and the orderer and master of the wedding feast, and of all the friends of the Bridegrome. Revel. 22.17. Christ saith (for it is his revelation to John, Chap. 1.1.) Come, in all those comes there. None could speak that, unlesse Christ first spake it. And the Spirit (the Architriclinus: that Master of the feast) saith, Come. And the Bride, the Churches, all the Saints converted, out of their own sweet experience of coming to Christ say, Come. And let him that heareth, every Minister that hears the Church says so, that hath his commission or call from Christ by the Church, saying, Come. And what do they all say? Let him that is athirst, come. If thou hast a will, doubt not of Christs will. His impression of willingnesse on thy will, is a sealed expression
of his willingnesse. And what more? And whosoever will (whether with an hungring will, or a wishing will, or a woulding will, so that he will) let him take of the waters of life freely. He freely gives freely offers, freely invites, therefore freely, freely, freely may he take. Thou canst name no Case of Conscience to keep thee off, that hast a will to come; or comest (if it be possible) without a will. Him that cometh (saith Christ) I will in no wise, in no case cast out. Thou canst not imagine any sin, if thou comest to Christ, that can keep thee off. He doth not onely swear, (and Christ cannot be perjured) that indefinitely he desires not the death of a sinner. Ezek. 33.11. but he saith more fully, viz: universally, He is not willing that ANY should perish. 2 Pet. 3.9. Not blasphemous or persecuters, for he called Paul. Not murtherers, nor fornicators, nor idolaters, nor effeminate, nor Sodomites, nor theeves, nor covetous, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners, for such had been some of the Corinthians, but God justified and sanctified them. 1 Cor. 6.9, 10. Nor such as have been possessed with the devil; for Christ called and accepted of Mary Magdalene; nor such as have been conjurers, for to such also hath Christ given repentance. Act. 19.19. So that if any stand out, and not come to Christ, Thy destruction is of thy self O man; as God said to Israel. To them under the Gospel this is the rule. All men by the least sin are damnable. Eves desiring-look on the apple, the Angels first evil thought cast them out of their blessed condition: But man by the greatest sin that is, is not damned, unlesse this be added, that he comes not to Christ. Joh. 3. often.

Therefore why, O ye sons of men, stand ye still in a damnable-mistaken-doubting condition, so as not to come to Christ? Why will ye dye? Ezek. 18. you need not perish, unlesse you will perish; no reason in Christs will, but in your will. To him that hath shall be given. You never improve the least gift to go onward towards Christ, but he prospers it to more. What would you have more, then a Christ suffering, a Christ offering, a Christ intreating that you may come. Yea, (that all pretences may be removed) a Christ interceding that you may come, and beleeve. Joh. 17.20. Neither pray I for these alone,
(meaning his disciples that then beleeved on him) but for them also which shall beleeve on me through their word; that is, through the preaching of the Gospel by his disciples, namely, Apostles, and Evangelists, &c. to the end of the world. This intercession of Christ is called a saving to the uttermost them that come to him. Because he ever liveth to make intercession for them. So that whereas if the death and resurrection of Christ be propounded for our salvation, we may say, those are done and past, and we are not the better, or if the word & prayer, and other ordinances be urged to us, as still in doing, we may say, those are weak, and do not over-power our spirits; the Apostle puts an emphasis on Christs intercession, to shew its eminencie to answer to both these replyes. 1. That he ever liveth to make intercession for them that come; so that this is still in doing, to make his death and resurrection that are past and done, still to be in force, and of efficacy. 2. That whereas ordinan • es may seem weak, his intercession saveth to the uttermost them▪ that come; to obtain a power on ordinances to save, and to make up what is wanting in them.

But to return to the point in hand, to carry on our designe, of carrying thee, O sinner, home to Christ. Out of the mouth of this point proceeds Answers to all objections; satisfaction to all scruples, removall of all obstructions; and a discovery of all disputes against it to be but pretences. Let any man but weigh Christs words and method in relation to the text and point in hand, and let him object and dispute any thing to purpose if he can. Christ in that Revel. 22.17. (a notable parallel, and sutable place to the text) having in the former part of that book set forth by great promises, and glorious representations that he will come, to make men Saints, and Saints to be a glorious universall Church; in the close (in the said Revel. 22.) he proclaims, that men should meet him in their desires for the designe in hand, saying, Let men say, Come; not onely the spirituall Spouse, but he (whosoever he be) that heareth, says, Come, and then presently Christ ecchoes, resounds twise to those two, Let him that thirsteth, come; let him that will, come: most sutable to the text. If thou doest not keep out
(whosoever thou art) Christ will not cast thee out. And therefore that of the Prophet may fitly be here applyed, Thy destruction is of thy self O Israel. For the Lord is not willing that any should perish: 2 Pet. 3.9. And he doth not onely say so, who cannot lye, (Tit. 1.2.) but swears so, (Ezek. 33.11.) who cannot be perjured. As I live, saith the Lord, I d • s •• e not the dea • h of a sinner. He swears by the choicest attribute, H •• life, that is the root of all others, and the excellencie of his being; and therefore carries a great deal of weight with it, that in good earnest and most cordially God is not willing that any should perish, should dye eternally. Not blasphemers (to give some instances) or persecuters, see in the calling of Paul. Not murtherers, see in the conversion of Manasses. Not adulterers, or those prevailed on by the devil, see in the taking of Mary Magdalen into grace and favour. All the least sins in themselves are damnable (the angels are damned for their first evil thoughts they had in heaven.) But the greatest sinners under the Gospel are not damned, unlesse they adde this, they slight the offer of Christ, and do not beleeve in him: Joh. 3. oft. Why therefore, I say again, O ye sons of men, stand ye still in a damnable condition, and not chme in to Christ? why do you make any stay in a mistaken, doubting condition, and do not throw away all, and throw your selves upon your Saviour? The Lord demands with much earnestnesse (in that Ezek. 18.31.) Why will ye dye G house of Israel? can ye shew, can ye imagine any reason? you need not perish, unlesse you will need •
perish. There is no reason in God, but in your wils. All this that place holds forth. And therefore still I cry O sinners, what would you have more? you have a Christ that hath suffered for you; you have a Christ that hath offered himself to you; a God that hath sent him to you; a God that invites you to him; and if you come, you shall not be disappointed, saith the text. Joh. 6.37. Though you may put many cases, yet Christ saith, In no wise will he keep you out. All which so fully and freely declare the minde of God in Christ to poore sinners, as that nothing more can be said; as Isa. 5.4. What could have been done more unto my vineyard, that I have not done? And Hos. 6.4.
O Ephraim, what shall I do unto thee? O Judah, what shall I do unto thee? Consider now O sinner, look about thee, God acquits himself; therefore the fault must lye in thee. If thou doest improve what thou hast, To him that hath, shall be given. Though Gods will doth not depend on mans, yet God will be tyed to his own engagement, and do as he hath said.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Profane men may and must come in to Christ, notwithstanding former presumptions and despairs.
div.p: YEt for all the text and point in hand, many stand off, dispute, cavil, and come not in to Christ: As, 1. Profane men; 2. Hipocriticall professors. 3. Embrions, that is, imperfect, or new-conceptions of Christianity, but not yet shaped, and formed to maturitie of a compleat birth. But the point in hand well managed will confute them all.
1. Profane men stand out upon two extreames. 1. Presumption. 2. Despair. And this usually follows that.

1. Upon presumption. And why? they can (as they interpretatively think) do well enough without Christ. For they seek not after him. But if this were true, why then did Christ coming into the world, make this proposition, this offer of himself to you? It seems Christ well knows you have dear need of him. Yea and you (profane men) seem also sometimes to know that you need some such things as a Christ. For else, while you are out of Christ, why doth your conscience somtimes, for some sins give you some short and sharp bitings? why do you in your afflictions, or when you are (as you think) upon your dying pillow, so oft repeat these words, For Christs sake, O for Christ his sake? sure you think that God cannot in justice save you without satisfaction; That Christ did not dye in vain, namely, there was need of him for such as you are. That Christ did not speak and pen this text in vain, but for your necessity. If you reply, you have
Christ, for you professe him, and beleeve his word to be true; we must needs then quaere with you, how can you be said truly to have Christ, and really live in your profanesse? have you Christ, and are ye lyars too? have you Christ, and are ye swearers too? Is Christ a profane Christ? If not; how shall Christ and the Belials of wickednesses dwell together?
If you object, no man is without sin; We answer:

1. That he that is truly in Christ, is without a will to sin. Rom. 7. 1 Joh. 3.8, 9. He cannot yeeld with a full will to sin. There is a strong inward reluctation against it. 2. That he is without grosse sins in practise. 3. Without a custome in any known sin. 4. He continually goes to Christ to be more sanctified, and so should you.

2. Despair sometimes keep men off from Christ. When the devil cannot keep them off in one extreame, then he labours to keep them off in another. And for this purpose he arms them with many unreasonable objections.
Obj. 1. Saith the Despairer, my sins are too many, too great, of too long continuance to be pardoned by Christ.

Ans: If this were true, why doth not Christ make this exception in the text? Doth he not say just the contrary, that him that cometh to him, he will in NO WISE cast out? Hath he any where excluded sins, because many or great, or of long continuance from pardon, whiles he offers it in the ordinances? Is not Christ true, and able, and willing to make good his word? Is there any sin thou hast committed which he hath not pardoned to another? might not Judas his sin have been pardoned, had he come to Christ, as well as others committing the same sin? Act. 2.36. Sure when he saith, In no wise will he cast out any that come to him, he hath an unlimited satisfaction for, & compassion to all sorts of sinners, in all sorts of sin that come to him. As Isa. 55.1, &c. If any thirst, if any will call upon him, seek to him, lay aside his own thoughts, and hearken to Christs, he will have mercy, to take away all sorts of sinfull miseries; he will abundantly pardon (or as it is in the Hebrew, he will multiply to pardon, to take away the numerousnesse of sins. And his thoughts are (he saith) above our thoughts, as high as the heavens are above
the earth, to take away the greatnesse of sins. And he will make his word effectuall, as the rain upon the earth to stop the continuance of sin. For indeed his mercy is infinite, as well in perpetuitie as immensitie. And all such high, and comprehensive expressions of mercy, are more expresly and particularly entailed on such a bleeding heart as thine is, as Chirurgions most look to the most broken, and wounded. Isa. 66.2. Isa. 57.15. Matth. 12.20. Luk. 4.18, 19. look these places in the said quotations, and consider them. If thou be wounded indeed in spirit, thou wilt turn to them, and study them.
Obj. 2. Saith the despairer, I have so many, and so great afflictions, that God seems to signifie to me by them, that he means to damne me.

Ans. This is no good argument. For if it had; then Christ would not have said without limitation, Him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out; be his afflictions never so many or great, or grim in shew of signification. For indeed no man can conclude God hates him, by his affliction. Eccles. 9.1. Rather he may conclude from his affliction, that God loves him. 1 Cor. 11.32. Hebr. 12.7. And that to have no affliction, is rather a signe of Gods hate. Isa. 1.5. Hebr. 12.8.
Obj. 3. But saith the despairer, God hath forsaken me. I cannot pray, I cannot hear as sometimes I could.

Ans: The text doth not run upon those terms of so praying, or so hearing; or whether thou didst pray or hear formerly. The question is, whether thou doest now by praying, hearing, or any how so look after Christ as now to come, now to scrabble to him, to sigh for him, to be restlesse for him? such a one Christ will in no wise cast out. And for his forsaking thee; God usually doth never forsake man remedilesly, till he forsake him with refusing of the remedie. 2 Chron. 36.15, 16. Prov. 29.1. If by forsaking thou meanest a temporary partiall forsaking, which we call desertion, that is, a withdrawing of assistance, and inward feeling of comfort; this condition of desertion simply in it self is not sinfull: for Christ was in it. However God withdraws, in case thou perceivest it, complainest of it, grievest for it (as thy objection is here)
this may be in godly persons: Isa. 63.17. say the Saints there, O Lord why hast thou made us to erre from thy wayes, and hardned our hearts from thy fear? And yet in the verse before they say to the Lord, Doubtlesse thou art our Father; and in the close of the 17. verse, they pray earnestly to the Lord to return. So they that fear the Lord may be in darknesse, and see no light. Isa. 50.10. And godly Jonah said, Jonah 2.4. I am cast out of thy sight. So David, Psal. 22.1.
Obj. 4. But saith the despairing despondent soul, I am afraid I have sinned the sin against the holy Ghost.

Ans: 1.
